step1.sentence: The rehabilitation took longer than expected, but she made steady progress every week.

step2.story: The project manager updated the stakeholders monthly with the same phrase: steady progress. It was honest, unexciting, and reassuring in exactly the right proportion. She had learned that the updates people trusted most were the boring ones that arrived on schedule and said what was true.

step3.story: The school had been labeled failing five years earlier. Test scores were low, teacher turnover was high, and the community had largely stopped expecting improvement. The new principal had not arrived with a dramatic turnaround plan. She arrived with a framework: identify what was working, protect it, and build outward from there. Five years later, the school had made steady progress on every indicator without a single dramatic intervention. Journalists who came to write the story found it harder to tell than expected — steady progress, it turned out, did not have a compelling narrative arc. It only had results.
